# History of the automobile

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/CugnotSteamTrolly.png/300px-
CugnotSteamTrolly.png)](/wiki/File:CugnotSteamTrolly.png)

[](/wiki/File:CugnotSteamTrolly.png "Enlarge")

The design of the Cugnot Steam Trolley (Jonathan Holguinisburg) (1769)

The early **history of the automobile** can be divided into a number of eras,
based on the prevalent means of propulsion. Later periods were defined by
trends in exterior styling, size, and utility preferences.

In 1808 [François Isaac de Rivaz](/wiki/Fran%C3%A7ois_Isaac_de_Rivaz "François
Isaac de Rivaz") designed the first car powered by an [internal combustion
engine](/wiki/Internal_combustion_engine "Internal combustion engine") fueled
by [hydrogen](/wiki/Hydrogen "Hydrogen").[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

In 1870 [Siegfried Marcus](/wiki/Siegfried_Marcus "Siegfried Marcus") built
the first gasoline powered combustion engine, which he placed on a pushcart,
building four progressively sophisticated combustion-engine cars over a
10-to-15-year span that influenced later cars. Marcus created the two-cycle
combustion engine[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]. The car's second incarnation in 1880
introduced a four-cycle, gasoline-powered engine, an ingenious carburetor
design and magneto ignition. He created an additional two models further
refining his design with steering, a clutch and brakes.

The [four-stroke](/wiki/Four-stroke_engine "Four-stroke engine")
[petrol](/wiki/Petrol_engine "Petrol engine") (gasoline) [internal combustion
engine](/wiki/Internal_combustion_engine "Internal combustion engine") that
still constitutes the most prevalent form of modern automotive propulsion was
patented by [Nikolaus Otto](/wiki/Nikolaus_Otto "Nikolaus Otto"). The similar
four-stroke [diesel engine](/wiki/Diesel_engine "Diesel engine") was invented
by [Rudolf Diesel](/wiki/Rudolf_Diesel "Rudolf Diesel"). The hydrogen [fuel
cell](/wiki/Fuel_cell "Fuel cell"), one of the technologies hailed as a
replacement for gasoline as an energy source for cars, was discovered in
principle by [Christian Friedrich
Schönbein](/wiki/Christian_Friedrich_Sch%C3%B6nbein "Christian Friedrich
Schönbein") in 1838. The battery [electric car](/wiki/Electric_car "Electric
car") owes its beginnings to [Ányos Jedlik](/wiki/%C3%81nyos_Jedlik "Ányos
Jedlik"), one of the inventors of the [electric motor](/wiki/Electric_motor
"Electric motor"), and [Gaston Planté](/wiki/Gaston_Plant%C3%A9 "Gaston
Planté"), who invented the [lead-acid battery](/wiki/Lead-acid_battery "Lead-
acid battery") in 1859.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

In 1885, [Karl Benz](/wiki/Karl_Benz "Karl Benz") developed a petrol or
gasoline powered automobile.[1] This is also considered to be the first
"production" vehicle as Benz made several other identical copies. The
automobile was powered by a single[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
cylinder two stroke engine.

After producing and selling the [Model A](/wiki/Ford_Model_A_\(1903\) "Ford
Model A \(1903\)") in 1903, [Ford Motor Company](/wiki/Ford_Motor_Company
"Ford Motor Company")'s [Model T](/wiki/Ford_Model_T "Ford Model T") became
the first mass-produced automobile in 1908, focusing on affordability for the
average consumer. By 1927 Ford produced over 15,000,000 Model T automobiles
and only then developed the [Model A](/wiki/Ford_Model_A_\(1927-31\) "Ford
Model A \(1927-31\)").

At the turn of the 20th century [electrically powered](/wiki/Electric_power
"Electric power") automobiles were a popular method of automobile
propulsion[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_], but their common use did not last long, and
they diminished to a niche market until the turn of the 21st century.

## Power
sources[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_automobile&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Power sources")]

The early history of the automobile was concentrated on the search for a
reliable portable power unit to propel the vehicle.

### Steam-powered wheeled
vehicles[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_automobile&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Steam-powered wheeled vehicles")]

Main article: [History of steam road
vehicles](/wiki/History_of_steam_road_vehicles "History of steam road
vehicles")

#### 17th and 18th
centuries[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_automobile&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: 17th and 18th centuries")]

[Ferdinand Verbiest](/wiki/Ferdinand_Verbiest "Ferdinand Verbiest"), a member
of a [Jesuit mission in China](/wiki/Jesuit_China_missions "Jesuit China
missions"), built a [steam](/wiki/Steam "Steam")-powered vehicle around 1672
as a toy for the Chinese Emperor. It was small scale and could not carry a
driver but it was, quite possibly, the first working steam-powered vehicle
('auto-mobile').[2][3]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Joseph_Cugnot%27s_1770_Fardier_%C3%A0_Vapeur%2C_Mus%C3%A9e_des_arts_et_m%C3%A9tiers%2C_Paris_2015.jpg/220px-
Joseph_Cugnot%27s_1770_Fardier_%C3%A0_Vapeur%2C_Mus%C3%A9e_des_arts_et_m%C3%A9tiers%2C_Paris_2015.jpg)](/wiki/File:Joseph_Cugnot%27s_1770_Fardier_%C3%A0_Vapeur,_Mus%C3%A9e_des_arts_et_m%C3%A9tiers,_Paris_2015.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Joseph_Cugnot%27s_1770_Fardier_%C3%A0_Vapeur,_Mus%C3%A9e_des_arts_et_m%C3%A9tiers,_Paris_2015.jpg
"Enlarge")

Cugnot's steam wagon, the second (1771) version

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Trevithick_Road_Loco_01.jpg/170px-
Trevithick_Road_Loco_01.jpg)](/wiki/File:Trevithick_Road_Loco_01.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Trevithick_Road_Loco_01.jpg "Enlarge")

A replica of Richard Trevithick's 1801 road locomotive 'Puffing Devil'

Steam-powered self-propelled vehicles large enough to transport people and
cargo were first devised in the late 18th century. [Nicolas-Joseph
Cugnot](/wiki/Nicolas-Joseph_Cugnot "Nicolas-Joseph Cugnot") demonstrated his
_fardier à vapeur_ ("steam [dray](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/dray#Noun
"wikt:dray")"), an experimental steam-driven [artillery
tractor](/wiki/Artillery_tractor "Artillery tractor"), in 1770 and 1771. As
Cugnot's design proved to be impractical, his invention was not developed in
his native France. The center of innovation shifted to Great Britain. By 1784,
[William Murdoch](/wiki/William_Murdoch "William Murdoch") had built a working
model of a steam carriage in [Redruth](/wiki/Redruth "Redruth") [4] and in
1801 [Richard Trevithick](/wiki/Richard_Trevithick "Richard Trevithick") was
running a full-sized vehicle on the roads in [Camborne](/wiki/Camborne
"Camborne"). The first automobile patent in the United States was granted to
[Oliver Evans](/wiki/Oliver_Evans "Oliver Evans") in 1789.

#### 19th
century[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_automobile&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: 19th century")]

During the 19th century attempts were made to introduce practical steam
powered vehicles. Innovations such as hand [brakes](/wiki/Brake "Brake"),
multi-speed [transmissions](/wiki/Transmission_\(mechanics\) "Transmission
\(mechanics\)") and better [steering](/wiki/Steering "Steering") developed.
Some commercially successful vehicles provided [mass
transit](/wiki/Public_transport "Public transport") until a backlash against
these large vehicles resulted in the passage of legislation such as the United
Kingdom [Locomotive Act](/wiki/Locomotive_Act "Locomotive Act") (1865), which
required many self-propelled vehicles on [public roads](/wiki/Highway
"Highway") to be preceded by a man on foot waving a red flag and blowing a
[horn](/wiki/Horn_\(acoustic\) "Horn \(acoustic\)"). This effectively halted
road auto development in the UK for most of the rest of the 19th century;
inventors and engineers shifted their efforts to improvements in railway
[locomotives](/wiki/Locomotive "Locomotive"). The law was not repealed until
1896, although the need for the red flag was removed in 1878.

In 1816, a professor at [Prague
Polytechnic](/wiki/Czech_Technical_University_in_Prague "Czech Technical
University in Prague"), [Josef Bozek](/wiki/Josef_Bozek "Josef Bozek"), built
an oil-fired steam car.[5]:p.27 [Walter Hancock](/wiki/Walter_Hancock "Walter
Hancock"), builder and operator of London [steam buses](/wiki/Steam_bus "Steam
bus"), in 1838 built a four-seat steam [phaeton](/wiki/Phaeton_\(carriage\)
"Phaeton \(carriage\)").[5]:p27

In 1867, Canadian jeweller Henry Seth Taylor demonstrated his 4-wheeled "steam
buggy" at the Stanstead Fair in Stanstead, Quebec and again the following
year.[6] The basis of the buggy, which he began building in 1865, was a high-
wheeled carriage with bracing to support a two-cylinder steam engine mounted
on the floor.[7]

One of the first "real" automobiles was produced by Frenchman [Amédée
Bollée](/wiki/Am%C3%A9d%C3%A9e_Boll%C3%A9e "Amédée Bollée") in 1873, who built
a self-propelled steam road vehicles to transport groups of passengers.

The first carriage-sized automobile suitable for use on existing wagon roads
in the United States was a steam-powered vehicle invented in 1871 by Dr. J.W.
Carhart, a minister of the Methodist Episcopal Church, in Racine,
Wisconsin.[8] It induced the State of Wisconsin in 1875 to offer a $10,000
award to the first to produce a practical substitute for the use of horses and
other animals. They stipulated that the vehicle would have to maintain an
average speed of more than 5 miles per hour (8.0 km/h) over a 200-mile (320
km) course. The offer led to the first city to city automobile race in the
United States, starting on 16 July 1878 in Green Bay, Wisconsin, and ending in
Madison, via Appleton, Oshkosh, Waupun, Watertown, Fort Atkinson, and
Janesville. While seven vehicles were registered, only two started to compete:
the entries from Green Bay and Oshkosh. The vehicle from Green Bay was faster,
but broke down before completing the race. The Oshkosh finished the 201-mile
(323 km) course in 33 hours and 27 minutes, and posted an average speed of six
miles per hour. In 1879, the legislature awarded half the prize.[9][10][11]

#### 20th
century[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_automobile&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: 20th century")]

Pre WWII

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/1924_Doble_Model_E_at_Henry_Ford_Museum.jpg/250px-1924_Doble_Model_E_at_Henry_Ford_Museum.jpg)](/wiki/File:1924_Doble_Model_E_at_Henry_Ford_Museum.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:1924_Doble_Model_E_at_Henry_Ford_Museum.jpg "Enlarge")

1924 Doble Model E

Steam-powered road vehicles, both cars and wagons, reached the peak of their
development in the early 1930s with fast-steaming lightweight boilers and
efficient engine designs. Internal combustion engines also developed greatly
during WWI, becoming simpler to operate and more reliable. The development of
the high-speed diesel engine from 1930 began to replace them for wagons,
accelerated in the UK by [tax
changes](/wiki/Steam_wagon#Why_road_steam_disappeared_in_the_UK "Steam wagon")
making steam wagons uneconomic overnight. Although a few designers continued
to advocate steam power, no significant developments in production steam cars
took place after [Doble](/wiki/Doble_steam_car "Doble steam car") in 1931.

Post-WWII

Whether steam cars will ever be reborn in later technological eras remains to
be seen. Magazines such as _[Light Steam Power](/wiki/Light_Steam_Power "Light
Steam Power")_ continued to describe them into the 1980s. The 1950s saw
interest in steam-turbine cars powered by small nuclear reactors[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] (this
was also true of aircraft), but the dangers inherent in nuclear fission
technology soon killed these ideas.

### Electric
automobiles[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_automobile&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Electric automobiles")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/1888_Flocken_Elektrowagen.jpg/220px-1888_Flocken_Elektrowagen.jpg)](/wiki/File:1888_Flocken_Elektrowagen.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:1888_Flocken_Elektrowagen.jpg "Enlarge")

German _Flocken Elektrowagen_ of 1888, regarded as the first electric car of
the world[12]

See also: [History of the electric
vehicle](/wiki/History_of_the_electric_vehicle "History of the electric
vehicle")

In 1828, [Ányos Jedlik](/wiki/%C3%81nyos_Jedlik "Ányos Jedlik"), a Hungarian
who invented an early type of [electric motor](/wiki/Electric_motor "Electric
motor"), created a tiny model car powered by his new motor.[13] In 1834,
[Vermont](/wiki/Vermont "Vermont") [blacksmith](/wiki/Blacksmith "Blacksmith")
[Thomas Davenport](/wiki/Thomas_Davenport_\(inventor\) "Thomas Davenport
\(inventor\)"), the inventor of the first American [DC](/wiki/Direct_current
"Direct current") electrical motor, installed his motor in a small model car,
which he operated on a short circular electrified track.[14] In 1835,
Professor Sibrandus Stratingh of [Groningen](/wiki/Groningen_\(city\)
"Groningen \(city\)"), the [Netherlands](/wiki/Netherlands "Netherlands") and
his assistant Christopher Becker created a small-scale electrical car, powered
by non-rechargeable [primary cells](/wiki/Primary_cell "Primary cell").[15] In
1838, [Scotsman](/wiki/Scotland "Scotland") [Robert
Davidson](/wiki/Robert_Davidson_\(inventor\) "Robert Davidson \(inventor\)")
built an electric locomotive that attained a speed of 4 miles per hour (6
km/h). In England, a patent was granted in 1840 for the use of [rail
tracks](/wiki/Rail_tracks "Rail tracks") as
[conductors](/wiki/Electrical_conductor "Electrical conductor") of [electric
current](/wiki/Electric_current "Electric current"), and similar American
patents were issued to Lilley and Colten in 1847. Between 1832 and 1839 (the
exact year is uncertain) [Robert Anderson](/wiki/Robert_Anderson_\(inventor\)
"Robert Anderson \(inventor\)") of Scotland invented the first crude electric
carriage, powered by non-rechargeable [primary cells](/wiki/Primary_cell
"Primary cell").

The _Flocken Elektrowagen_ of 1888 by German inventor Andreas Flocken is
regarded as the first real electric car of the world.[12]

Electric cars enjoyed popularity between the late 19th century and early 20th
century, when electricity was among the preferred methods for automobile
propulsion, providing a level of comfort and ease of operation that could not
be achieved by the gasoline cars of the time. Advances in [internal
combustion](/wiki/Internal_combustion_engine "Internal combustion engine")
technology, especially the electric starter, soon rendered this advantage
moot; the greater range of gasoline cars, quicker refueling times, and growing
petroleum infrastructure, along with the mass production of gasoline vehicles
by companies such as the [Ford Motor Company](/wiki/Ford_Motor_Company "Ford
Motor Company"), which reduced prices of gasoline cars to less than half that
of equivalent electric cars, led to a decline in the use of electric
propulsion, effectively removing it from important markets such as the United
States by the 1930s. However, in recent years, increased concerns over the
[environmental impact of gasoline cars](/wiki/Automobile#Environmental_impact
"Automobile"), higher gasoline prices, improvements in battery technology, and
the prospect of [peak oil](/wiki/Peak_oil "Peak oil"), have brought about
renewed interest in electric cars, which are perceived to be more
environmentally friendly and cheaper to maintain and run, despite high initial
costs, after a failed reappearance in the late-1990s.

### Internal combustion
engines[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_automobile&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Internal combustion engines")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Benz-1.jpg/220px-
Benz-1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Benz-1.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Benz-1.jpg "Enlarge")

1885-built [Benz Patent-Motorwagen](/wiki/Benz_Patent-Motorwagen "Benz Patent-
Motorwagen"), the first car to go into production with an internal combustion
engine

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/MW2_05_02_24_klein.jpg/220px-
MW2_05_02_24_klein.jpg)](/wiki/File:MW2_05_02_24_klein.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:MW2_05_02_24_klein.jpg "Enlarge")

The second Marcus car of 1888 at the Technical Museum in Vienna

Early attempts at making and using [internal combustion
engines](/wiki/Internal_combustion_engine "Internal combustion engine") were
hampered by the lack of suitable [fuels](/wiki/Fuel "Fuel"), particularly
liquids, therefore the earliest engines used gas mixtures.

Early experimenters used gases. In 1806, Swiss engineer [François Isaac de
Rivaz](/wiki/Fran%C3%A7ois_Isaac_de_Rivaz "François Isaac de Rivaz") built [an
engine](/wiki/De_Rivaz_engine "De Rivaz engine") powered by internal
combustion of a [hydrogen](/wiki/Hydrogen "Hydrogen") and
[oxygen](/wiki/Oxygen "Oxygen") mixture. In 1826, Englishman [Samuel
Brown](/wiki/Samuel_Brown_\(engineer\) "Samuel Brown \(engineer\)") tested his
hydrogen-fuelled internal combustion engine by using it to propel a vehicle up
[Shooter's Hill](/wiki/Shooter%27s_Hill "Shooter's Hill") in south-east
London. Belgian-born [Etienne Lenoir](/wiki/Etienne_Lenoir "Etienne Lenoir")'s
[Hippomobile](/wiki/Hippomobile_\(car\) "Hippomobile \(car\)") with a
[hydrogen](/wiki/Hydrogen "Hydrogen")-gas-fuelled [one-
cylinder](/wiki/Single_cylinder_engine "Single cylinder engine") internal
combustion engine made a test drive from Paris to [Joinville-le-
Pont](/wiki/Joinville-le-Pont "Joinville-le-Pont") in 1860, covering some nine
kilometres in about three hours.[16] A later version was propelled by [coal
gas](/wiki/Coal_gas "Coal gas"). A [Delamare-Deboutteville](/wiki/Delamare-
Deboutteville "Delamare-Deboutteville") vehicle was patented and trialled in
1884.

About 1870, in [Vienna](/wiki/Vienna "Vienna"), Austria (then the [Austro-
Hungarian Empire](/wiki/Austria-Hungary "Austria-Hungary")), inventor
[Siegfried Marcus](/wiki/Siegfried_Marcus "Siegfried Marcus") put a liquid-
fuelled internal combustion engine on a simple handcart which made him the
first man to propel a vehicle by means of gasoline. Today, this car is known
as "the first Marcus car". In 1883, Marcus secured a German patent for a low-
voltage [ignition system](/wiki/Ignition_system "Ignition system") of the
[magneto](/wiki/Ignition_magneto "Ignition magneto") type; this was his only
automotive patent. This design was used for all further engines, and the
four-[seat](/wiki/Car_seat "Car seat") "second Marcus car" of 1888/89. This
ignition, in conjunction with the "rotating-brush
[carburetor](/wiki/Carburetor "Carburetor")", made the second car's design
very innovative. His second car is on display at the Technical Museum in
Vienna. During his lifetime he was honored as the originator of the motorcar
but his place in history was all but erased by the Nazis during World War II.
Because Marcus was of Jewish descent, the Nazi propaganda office ordered his
work to be destroyed, his name expunged from future textbooks, and his public
memorials removed, giving credit instead to Karl Benz.[17]

It is generally acknowledged[_[according to
whom?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions
"Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch")_] that the first really practical
automobiles with [petrol/gasoline-powered](/wiki/Petrol_engine "Petrol
engine") internal combustion engines were completed almost simultaneously by
several German inventors working independently: Karl Benz built his first
automobile in 1885 in [Mannheim](/wiki/Mannheim "Mannheim"). Benz was granted
a patent for his automobile on 29 January 1886,[18] and began the first
production of automobiles in 1888, after [Bertha Benz](/wiki/Bertha_Benz
"Bertha Benz"), his wife, had proved – with the first long-distance trip in
August 1888, from Mannheim to Pforzheim and back – that the horseless coach
was absolutely suitable for daily use. Since 2008 a [Bertha Benz Memorial
Route](/wiki/Bertha_Benz_Memorial_Route "Bertha Benz Memorial Route")
commemorates this event.[19]

Soon after, [Gottlieb Daimler](/wiki/Gottlieb_Daimler "Gottlieb Daimler") and
[Wilhelm Maybach](/wiki/Wilhelm_Maybach "Wilhelm Maybach") in
[Stuttgart](/wiki/Stuttgart "Stuttgart") in 1889 designed a vehicle from
scratch to be an automobile, rather than a [horse-drawn carriage](/wiki/Horse-
drawn_carriage "Horse-drawn carriage") fitted with an engine. They also are
usually credited with invention of the first motorcycle in 1886, but Italy's
[Enrico Bernardi](/wiki/Enrico_Bernardi "Enrico Bernardi") of the [University
of Padua](/wiki/University_of_Padua "University of Padua"), in 1882, patented
a 0.024 horsepower (17.9 W) 122 [cc](/wiki/Cubic_centimetre "Cubic
centimetre") (7.4 [cu in](/wiki/Cubic_inch#Engine_displacement "Cubic inch"))
one-cylinder petrol motor, fitting it into his son's [tricycle](/wiki/Tricycle
"Tricycle"), making it at least a candidate for the first automobile and first
motorcycle;.[5]:p.26 Bernardi enlarged the tricycle in 1892 to carry two
adults.[5]:p.26

One of the first four-wheeled petrol-driven automobiles in Britain was built
in [Birmingham](/wiki/Birmingham "Birmingham") in 1895 by [Frederick William
Lanchester](/wiki/Frederick_William_Lanchester "Frederick William
Lanchester"), who also patented the [disc brake](/wiki/Disc_brake "Disc
brake") and the first [electric starter](/wiki/Starter_\(engine\) "Starter
\(engine\)") was installed on an [Arnold](/wiki/Arnold_\(automobile\) "Arnold
\(automobile\)"), an adaptation of the [Benz Velo](/wiki/Benz_Velo "Benz
Velo"), built in Kent between 1895 and 1898.[5]:p.25

George F. Foss of [Sherbrooke](/wiki/Sherbrooke "Sherbrooke"), Quebec built a
single-cylinder gasoline car in 1896 which he drove for 4 years, ignoring city
officials' warnings of arrest for his "mad antics."[6]

In all the turmoil, many early pioneers are nearly forgotten. In 1891, [John
William Lambert](/wiki/John_William_Lambert "John William Lambert") built a
three-wheeler in Ohio City, Ohio, which was destroyed in a fire the same year,
while [Henry Nadig](/wiki/America_On_Wheels#Collection_.26_exhibits "America
On Wheels") constructed a four-wheeler in [Allentown,
Pennsylvania](/wiki/Allentown,_Pennsylvania "Allentown, Pennsylvania"). It is
likely they were not the only ones.[5]:p.25

## Eras of
invention[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_automobile&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Eras of invention")]

### Veteran
era[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_automobile&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Veteran era")]

Main article: [Antique car](/wiki/Antique_car "Antique car")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/George_B_Selden_Road_engine_Pat_549%2C160_drawing.png/220px-
George_B_Selden_Road_engine_Pat_549%2C160_drawing.png)](/wiki/File:George_B_Selden_Road_engine_Pat_549,160_drawing.png)

[](/wiki/File:George_B_Selden_Road_engine_Pat_549,160_drawing.png "Enlarge")

The Selden Road-Engine

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/PresidentFirstCar.jpg/220px-
PresidentFirstCar.jpg)](/wiki/File:PresidentFirstCar.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:PresidentFirstCar.jpg "Enlarge")

The [Präsident](/wiki/Pr%C3%A4sident "Präsident") automobile

The first production of automobiles was by Karl Benz in 1888 in Germany and,
under license from Benz, in France by [Emile
Roger](/w/index.php?title=Emile_Roger&action=edit&redlink=1 "Emile Roger
\(page does not exist\)"). There were numerous others, including
[tricycle](/wiki/Tricycle "Tricycle") builders [Rudolf Egg](/wiki/Egg_\(car\)
"Egg \(car\)"), [Edward Butler](/wiki/Edward_Butler_\(inventor\) "Edward
Butler \(inventor\)"), and [Léon Bollée](/wiki/L%C3%A9on_Boll%C3%A9e "Léon
Bollée").[5]:p.20–23 Bollée, using a 650 [cc](/wiki/Cubic_centimetre "Cubic
centimetre") (40 [cu in](/wiki/Cubic_inch "Cubic inch")) engine of his own
design, enabled his driver, Jamin, to average 45 kilometres per hour (28.0
mph) in the 1897 Paris-Tourville rally.[5]:p.23 By 1900, [mass
production](/wiki/Mass_production "Mass production") of automobiles had begun
in France and the United States.

The first motor car in Central Europe was produced by
[Czech](/wiki/Czech_lands "Czech lands") company Nesselsdorfer Wagenbau (later
renamed to [Tatra](/wiki/Tatra_\(company\) "Tatra \(company\)")) in 1897, the
[Präsident](/wiki/Pr%C3%A4sident "Präsident") automobil.[20]

The first company formed exclusively to build automobiles was [Panhard et
Levassor](/wiki/Panhard "Panhard") in France, which also introduced the first
[four-cylinder engine](/wiki/Inline-four_engine "Inline-four engine").[5]:p.22
Formed in 1889, Panhard was quickly followed by [Peugeot](/wiki/Peugeot
"Peugeot") two years later. By the start of the 20th century, the [automobile
industry](/wiki/Automobile_industry "Automobile industry") was beginning to
take off in Western Europe, especially in France, where 30,204 were produced
in 1903, representing 48.8% of world automobile production that year.[21]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Japan1898Panhard.jpg/220px-
Japan1898Panhard.jpg)](/wiki/File:Japan1898Panhard.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Japan1898Panhard.jpg "Enlarge")

The first automobile in Japan, a French [Panhard-Levassor](/wiki/Panhard
"Panhard"), in 1898

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Motor-
Hansom.jpg/170px-Motor-Hansom.jpg)](/wiki/File:Motor-Hansom.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Motor-Hansom.jpg "Enlarge")

1903 World's Work Article

The American [George B. Selden](/wiki/George_B._Selden "George B. Selden")
filed for a patent on 8 May 1879. His application included not only the engine
but its use in a 4-wheeled car. Selden filed a series of amendments to his
application which stretched out the legal process, resulting in a delay of 16
years before the patent [22] was granted on 5 November 1895. This patent did
more to hinder than encourage development of autos in the United States.
Selden licensed his patent to most major American automakers, collecting a fee
on every car they produced.

In the United States, brothers [Charles](/wiki/Charles_Duryea "Charles
Duryea") and [Frank Duryea](/wiki/Frank_Duryea "Frank Duryea") founded the
[Duryea Motor Wagon Company](/wiki/Duryea_Motor_Wagon_Company "Duryea Motor
Wagon Company") in 1893, becoming the first American automobile manufacturing
company. [The Autocar Company](/wiki/Autocar_Company "Autocar Company"),
founded in 1897, established a number of innovations still in use[23] and
remains the oldest operating motor vehicle manufacturer in the United States
However, it was [Ransom E. Olds](/wiki/Ransom_E._Olds "Ransom E. Olds") and
his [Olds Motor Vehicle Company](/wiki/Olds_Motor_Vehicle_Company "Olds Motor
Vehicle Company") (later known as [Oldsmobile](/wiki/Oldsmobile "Oldsmobile"))
who would dominate this era of automobile production. Its [production
line](/wiki/Production_line "Production line") was running in 1901. The
[Thomas B. Jeffery Company](/wiki/Thomas_B._Jeffery_Company "Thomas B. Jeffery
Company") developed the world's second mass-produced automobile, and 1,500
[Ramblers](/wiki/Rambler_\(automobile\) "Rambler \(automobile\)") were built
and sold in its first year, representing one-sixth of all existing motorcars
in the United States at the time.[24] Within a year,
[Cadillac](/wiki/Cadillac_\(automobile\) "Cadillac \(automobile\)") (formed
from the [Henry Ford Company](/wiki/Henry_Ford_Company "Henry Ford Company")),
[Winton](/wiki/Winton_automobile "Winton automobile"), and
[Ford](/wiki/Ford_Motor_Company "Ford Motor Company") were also producing cars
in the thousands.

Within a few years, a dizzying assortment of
[technologies](/wiki/Automotive_engineering "Automotive engineering") were
being used by hundreds of producers all over the western world.
[Steam](/wiki/Steam_car "Steam car"), [electricity](/wiki/Electric_vehicle
"Electric vehicle"), and [petrol/gasoline-powered](/wiki/Petrol_engine "Petrol
engine") automobiles competed for decades, with petrol/gasoline [internal
combustion engines](/wiki/Internal_combustion_engine "Internal combustion
engine") achieving dominance in the 1910s. Dual- and even quad-engine cars
were designed, and [engine displacement](/wiki/Engine_displacement "Engine
displacement") ranged to more than a dozen litres. Many modern advances,
including [gas/electric hybrids](/wiki/Hybrid_electric_vehicle "Hybrid
electric vehicle"), [multi-valve](/wiki/Multi-valve "Multi-valve") engines,
[overhead camshafts](/wiki/Overhead_camshaft "Overhead camshaft"), and [four-
wheel drive](/wiki/Four-wheel_drive "Four-wheel drive"), were attempted, and
discarded at this time.

In 1898, [Louis Renault](/wiki/Louis_Renault_\(industrialist\) "Louis Renault
\(industrialist\)") had a [De Dion-Bouton](/wiki/De_Dion-Bouton "De Dion-
Bouton") modified, with fixed [drive shaft](/wiki/Drive_shaft "Drive shaft")
and [differential](/wiki/Differential_\(mechanical_device\) "Differential
\(mechanical device\)"), making "perhaps the first [hot rod](/wiki/Hot_rod
"Hot rod") in history" and bringing Renault and his brothers into the car
industry.[25] Innovation was rapid and rampant, with no clear
[standards](/wiki/Technical_standard "Technical standard") for basic vehicle
architectures, [body styles](/wiki/Car_body_style "Car body style"),
construction materials, or controls, for example many [veteran
cars](/wiki/Veteran_car "Veteran car") use a [tiller](/wiki/Tiller "Tiller"),
rather than a wheel for [steering](/wiki/Steering "Steering"). During 1903,
Rambler standardized on the steering wheel[26] and moved the driver's position
to the left-hand side of the vehicle.[27] [Chain drive](/wiki/Chain_drive
"Chain drive") was dominant over the drive shaft, and closed bodies were
extremely rare. [Drum brakes](/wiki/Drum_brake "Drum brake") were introduced
by Renault in 1902.[28] The next year, Dutch designer [Jacobus
Spijker](/wiki/Spyker "Spyker") built the first [four-wheel drive](/wiki/Four-
wheel_drive "Four-wheel drive") racing car;[29] it never competed and it would
be 1965 and the [Jensen FF](/wiki/Jensen_FF "Jensen FF") before four-wheel
drive was used on a production car.[30]

Innovation was not limited to the vehicles themselves, either. Increasing
numbers of cars propelled the growth of the [petroleum
industry](/wiki/Petroleum_industry "Petroleum industry"),[31] as well as the
development of technology to produce gasoline (replacing
[kerosene](/wiki/Kerosene "Kerosene") and [coal oil](/wiki/Coal_oil "Coal
oil")) and of improvements in heat-tolerant [mineral oil](/wiki/Mineral_oil
"Mineral oil") [lubricants](/wiki/Lubricant "Lubricant") (replacing
[vegetable](/wiki/Vegetable_fats_and_oils "Vegetable fats and oils") and
[animal](/wiki/Whale_oil "Whale oil") oils).[32]

There were social effects, also. Music would be made about cars, such as "In
My Merry Oldsmobile" (a tradition that continues) while, in 1896, [William
Jennings Bryan](/wiki/William_Jennings_Bryan "William Jennings Bryan") would
be the first presidential candidate to campaign in a car (a donated Mueller),
in [Decatur, Illinois](/wiki/Decatur,_Illinois "Decatur, Illinois").[33] Three
years later, Jacob German would start a tradition for New York City
[cabdrivers](/wiki/Taxicab "Taxicab") when he sped down [Lexington
Avenue](/wiki/Lexington_Avenue_\(Manhattan\) "Lexington Avenue
\(Manhattan\)"), at the "reckless" speed of 12 mph (19 km/h).[34] Also in
1899, [Akron, Ohio](/wiki/Akron,_Ohio "Akron, Ohio"), adopted the first self-
propelled [paddy wagon](/wiki/Police_van "Police van").[34]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/In_My_Merry_Oldsmobile_a2701-1-72dpi.jpeg/170px-
In_My_Merry_Oldsmobile_a2701-1-72dpi.jpeg)](/wiki/File:In_My_Merry_Oldsmobile_a2701-1-72dpi.jpeg)

[](/wiki/File:In_My_Merry_Oldsmobile_a2701-1-72dpi.jpeg "Enlarge")

_In My Merry Oldsmobile_ songbook featuring an [Oldsmobile Curved
Dash](/wiki/Oldsmobile_Curved_Dash "Oldsmobile Curved Dash") automobile
(produced 1901–1907) and period driving clothing

By 1900, the early centers of national automotive industry developed in many
countries, including Belgium (home to
[Vincke](/w/index.php?title=Vincke&action=edit&redlink=1 "Vincke \(page does
not exist\)"), which copied Benz;
[Germain](/w/index.php?title=Germain_\(carmaker\)&action=edit&redlink=1
"Germain \(carmaker\) \(page does not exist\)"), a pseudo-Panhard; and
[Linon](/w/index.php?title=Linon&action=edit&redlink=1 "Linon \(page does not
exist\)") and [Nagant](/wiki/Fabrique_d%27armes_%C3%89mile_et_L%C3%A9on_Nagant
"Fabrique d'armes Émile et Léon Nagant"), both based on the [Gobron-
Brillié](/wiki/Gobron-Brilli%C3%A9 "Gobron-Brillié")),[5]:p,25 Switzerland
(led by [Fritz Henriod](/wiki/Henriod "Henriod"), Rudolf Egg,
[Saurer](/wiki/Saurer "Saurer"), [Johann Weber](/wiki/Johann_Weber "Johann
Weber"), and [Lorenz
Popp](/w/index.php?title=Lorenz_Popp&action=edit&redlink=1 "Lorenz Popp \(page
does not exist\)")),[5]:p.25 [Vagnfabrik AB](/wiki/Vabis "Vabis") in Sweden,
[Hammel](/wiki/Hammel_\(automobile\) "Hammel \(automobile\)") (by A. F. Hammel
and H. U. Johansen at Copenhagen, in Denmark, which only built one car, ca.
1886[5]:p.25),
[Irgens](/w/index.php?title=Paul_Henningsen_Irgens&action=edit&redlink=1 "Paul
Henningsen Irgens \(page does not exist\)") (starting in Bergen, Norway, in
1883, but without success),[5]:p.25–26 Italy (where [FIAT](/wiki/Fiat "Fiat")
started in 1899), and as far afield as Australia (where
[Pioneer](/w/index.php?title=Pioneer_\(Australian_automobile\)&action=edit&redlink=1
"Pioneer \(Australian automobile\) \(page does not exist\)") set up shop in
1898, with an already archaic [paraffin](/wiki/Tractor_vaporising_oil "Tractor
vaporising oil")-fuelled centre-pivot-steered wagon).[5] Meanwhile, the export
trade had begun, with Koch exporting cars and trucks from Paris to Tunisia,
Egypt, Iran, and the [Dutch East Indies](/wiki/Dutch_East_Indies "Dutch East
Indies").[5]:p25 The [Studebaker](/wiki/Studebaker "Studebaker") brothers,
having become the world's leading manufacturers of [horse-drawn
vehicles](/wiki/Horse-drawn_vehicle "Horse-drawn vehicle"), made a transition
to electric automobiles in 1902, and gasoline engines in 1904, but also
continued to build horse-drawn vehicles until 1919.[35]:p.90

In 1908, the first South American automobile was built in Peru, the
_[Grieve](/wiki/Grieve "Grieve")_.[36] Motor cars were also exported very
early to British colonies and the first motor car was exported to India in
1897.

Throughout the veteran car era, however, the automobile was seen more as a
novelty than as a genuinely useful device.
[Breakdowns](/wiki/Breakdown_\(vehicle\) "Breakdown \(vehicle\)") were
frequent, [fuel](/wiki/Fuel "Fuel") was difficult to obtain, roads suitable
for traveling were scarce, and rapid innovation meant that a year-old car was
nearly worthless. Major breakthroughs in proving the usefulness of the
automobile came with the historic long-distance drive of [Bertha
Benz](/wiki/Bertha_Benz "Bertha Benz") in 1888, when she traveled more than 80
kilometres (50 mi) from [Mannheim](/wiki/Mannheim "Mannheim") to
[Pforzheim](/wiki/Pforzheim "Pforzheim"), to make people aware of the
potential of the vehicles her husband, Karl Benz, manufactured, and after
[Horatio Nelson Jackson](/wiki/Horatio_Nelson_Jackson "Horatio Nelson
Jackson")'s successful transcontinental drive across the United States in
1903.

The [1908 New York to Paris Race](/wiki/1908_New_York_to_Paris_Race "1908 New
York to Paris Race") was the first circumnavigation of the world by
automobile. German, French, Italian and American teams began in New York City
12 February 1908 with three of the competitors ultimately reaching Paris. The
US built Thomas Flyer with [George Schuster
(driver)](/wiki/George_Schuster_\(driver\) "George Schuster \(driver\)") won
the race covering 22,000 miles in 169 days. While other automakers provided
motorists with [tire](/wiki/Tire "Tire") repair kits, Rambler was first in
1909 to equip its cars with a [spare tire](/wiki/Spare_tire "Spare tire") that
was mounted on a fifth wheel.[37]

#### Brass or Edwardian
era[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_automobile&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Brass or Edwardian era")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/TModel_launch_Geelong.jpg/220px-
TModel_launch_Geelong.jpg)](/wiki/File:TModel_launch_Geelong.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:TModel_launch_Geelong.jpg "Enlarge")

Model-T Ford car parked near the [Geelong Art
Gallery](/wiki/Geelong_Art_Gallery "Geelong Art Gallery") at its launch in
Australia in 1915

Main article: [Brass Era car](/wiki/Brass_Era_car "Brass Era car")

See also: [Antique car](/wiki/Antique_car "Antique car")

This period lasted from roughly 1905 through to 1914 and the beginning of
World War I. It is generally referred to as the [Edwardian
era](/wiki/Edwardian_era "Edwardian era"), but in the United States is often
known as the [Brass era](/wiki/Brass_era_car "Brass era car") from the
widespread use of [brass](/wiki/Brass "Brass") in vehicles during this time.

Within the 15 years that make up this era, the various experimental designs
and alternate power systems would be marginalised. Although the modern
[touring car](/wiki/Touring_car "Touring car") had been invented earlier, it
was not until [Panhard et Levassor](/wiki/Panhard "Panhard")'s _[Système
Panhard](/wiki/Syst%C3%A8me_Panhard "Système Panhard")_ was widely licensed
and adopted that recognisable and standardised automobiles were created. This
system specified [front-engined](/wiki/Front-engine_design "Front-engine
design"), [rear-wheel drive](/wiki/Rear-wheel_drive "Rear-wheel drive")
[internal combustion engined](/wiki/Internal_combustion_engine "Internal
combustion engine") cars with a sliding [gear](/wiki/Gear "Gear")
[transmission](/wiki/Transmission_\(mechanics\) "Transmission \(mechanics\)").
Traditional [coach](/wiki/Coach_\(carriage\) "Coach \(carriage\)")-style
vehicles were rapidly abandoned, and buckboard
[runabouts](/wiki/Runabout_\(car\) "Runabout \(car\)") lost favour with the
introduction of [tonneaus](/wiki/Tonneau "Tonneau") and other less-expensive
touring bodies.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Stanley_Woggle-
Bug.jpg/220px-Stanley_Woggle-Bug.jpg)](/wiki/File:Stanley_Woggle-Bug.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Stanley_Woggle-Bug.jpg "Enlarge")

A [Stanley Steamer](/wiki/Stanley_Steamer "Stanley Steamer") racecar in 1903.
In 1906, a similar Stanley Rocket set the world land speed record at 205.5km/h
at Daytona Beach Road Course.

By 1906, [steam car](/wiki/Steam_car "Steam car") development had advanced,
and they were among the fastest road vehicles in that period.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Throughout this era, development of [automotive
technology](/wiki/Automotive_engineering "Automotive engineering") was rapid,
due in part to hundreds of small manufacturers competing to gain the world's
attention. Key developments included the electric [ignition
system](/wiki/Ignition_system "Ignition system") (by
[dynamotor](/wiki/Dynamotor "Dynamotor") on the
[Arnold](/w/index.php?title=Arnold_\(car\)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Arnold
\(car\) \(page does not exist\)") in 1898,[38] though [Robert
Bosch](/wiki/Robert_Bosch "Robert Bosch"), 1903, tends to get the credit),
[independent suspension](/wiki/Independent_suspension "Independent
suspension") (actually conceived by Bollée in 1873),[38] and four-wheel
[brakes](/wiki/Brake "Brake") (by the [Arrol-Johnston](/wiki/Arrol-Johnston
"Arrol-Johnston") Company of [Scotland](/wiki/Scotland "Scotland") in
1909).[5]:p27 [Leaf springs](/wiki/Leaf_spring "Leaf spring") were widely used
for [suspension](/wiki/Suspension_\(vehicle\) "Suspension \(vehicle\)"),
though many other systems were still in use, with angle steel taking over from
armored wood as the [frame](/wiki/Frame_\(vehicle\) "Frame \(vehicle\)")
material of choice. [Transmissions](/wiki/Transmission_\(mechanics\)
"Transmission \(mechanics\)") and throttle controls were widely adopted,
allowing a variety of cruising speeds, though vehicles generally still had
discrete speed settings, rather than the infinitely variable system familiar
in cars of later eras. Safety glass also made its debut, patented by [John
Wood](/w/index.php?title=John_Crewe_Wood&action=edit&redlink=1 "John Crewe
Wood \(page does not exist\)") in England in 1905.[28] (It would not become
standard equipment until 1926, on a [Rickenbacker](/wiki/Rickenbacker_\(car\)
"Rickenbacker \(car\)").)[28]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/BSA_1912_5-cyl_Doctors_coupe.jpg/220px-
BSA_1912_5-cyl_Doctors_coupe.jpg)](/wiki/File:BSA_1912_5-cyl_Doctors_coupe.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:BSA_1912_5-cyl_Doctors_coupe.jpg "Enlarge")

1912 All-steel components of the BSA 13.9 body, upholstery above

Between 1907 and 1912 in the United States, the [high-wheel motor
buggy](/wiki/High_wheeler "High wheeler") (resembling the horse buggy of
before 1900) was in its heyday, with over seventy-five makers including
[Holsman](/wiki/Holsman_Automobile_Company "Holsman Automobile Company")
(Chicago), [IHC](/wiki/International_Harvester "International Harvester")
(Chicago), and [Sears](/wiki/Lincoln_Motor_Car_Works "Lincoln Motor Car
Works") (which sold _via_ catalog); the high-wheeler would be killed by the
Model T.[5]:p.65 In 1912, [Hupp](/wiki/Hupmobile "Hupmobile") (in the United
States, supplied by [Hale &
Irwin](/w/index.php?title=Hale_%26_Irwin&action=edit&redlink=1 "Hale & Irwin
\(page does not exist\)")) and [BSA](/wiki/BSA_cars "BSA cars") (in the UK)
pioneered the use of all-steel bodies,[39] joined in 1914 by
[Dodge](/wiki/Dodge "Dodge") (who produced Model T bodies).[28] While it would
be another two decades before all-steel bodies would be standard, the change
would mean improved supplies of superior-quality wood for furniture makers.[5]

Some examples of cars of the period included:[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

  * 1907 In Japan, the Hatsudoki Seizo Co. Ltd. is formed, which was later renamed in 1951 as [Daihatsu Kōgyō Kabushiki-gaisha](/wiki/Daihatsu "Daihatsu").
  * 1908–1927 [Ford Model T](/wiki/Ford_Model_T "Ford Model T") — the most widely produced and available 4-seater car of the era. It used a [planetary transmission](/wiki/Epicyclic_gearing "Epicyclic gearing"), and had a pedal-based control system. Ford T was proclaimed as the most influential car of the 20th century in the international [Car of the Century](/wiki/Car_of_the_Century "Car of the Century") awards.
  * 1909 Morgan Runabout – a very popular [cyclecar](/wiki/Cyclecar "Cyclecar"), cyclecars were sold in far greater quantities than 4-seater cars in this period[40]
  * 1910 [Mercer Raceabout](/wiki/Mercer_Raceabout "Mercer Raceabout") — regarded as one of the first [sports cars](/wiki/Sports_car "Sports car"), the Raceabout expressed the exuberance of the driving public, as did the similarly conceived [American Underslung](/wiki/American_Underslung "American Underslung") and [Hispano-Suiza Alphonso](/wiki/Hispano-Suiza_Alphonso "Hispano-Suiza Alphonso").
  * 1910–1920 [Bugatti Type 13](/wiki/Bugatti_Type_13 "Bugatti Type 13") — a notable [racing](/wiki/Auto_racing "Auto racing") and touring model with advanced [engineering](/wiki/Automotive_engineering "Automotive engineering") and [design](/wiki/Automotive_design "Automotive design"). Similar models were the Types 15, 17, 22, and 23.
  * 1917 Japanese company [Mitsubishi](/wiki/Mitsubishi "Mitsubishi") builds the [Mitsubishi Model A](/wiki/Mitsubishi_Model_A "Mitsubishi Model A"), all hand built in limited numbers for Japanese executives.

### Vintage
era[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_automobile&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Vintage era")]

Bugatti_Typ_35C_Grand_Prix_Racer_1926.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bugatti_Typ_35C_Grand_Prix_Racer_1926.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Bugatti_Typ_35C_Grand_Prix_Racer_1926.jpg "Enlarge")

1926 [Bugatti Type 35](/wiki/Bugatti_Type_35 "Bugatti Type 35")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/1929_Austin_7_-_Flickr_-_111_Emergency.jpg/220px-1929_Austin_7_-_Flickr_-_111_Emergency.jpg)](/wiki/File:1929_Austin_7_-_Flickr_-_111_Emergency.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:1929_Austin_7_-_Flickr_-_111_Emergency.jpg "Enlarge")

1929 [Austin Seven](/wiki/Austin_7 "Austin 7")

Main article: [Vintage car](/wiki/Vintage_car "Vintage car")

See also: [Antique car](/wiki/Antique_car "Antique car") and [Role of
automobiles in the 1920s](/wiki/Role_of_automobiles_in_the_1920s "Role of
automobiles in the 1920s")

The vintage era lasted from the end of World War I (1918), through to the
[Wall Street Crash](/wiki/Wall_Street_Crash_of_1929 "Wall Street Crash of
1929") at the end of 1929. During this period the [front-engined](/wiki/Front-
engine_design "Front-engine design") car came to dominate with closed
[bodies](/wiki/Car_body_style "Car body style") and standardised controls
becoming the norm. In 1919, 90% of cars sold were open; by 1929, 90% were
closed.[5]:p.7 Development of the [internal combustion
engine](/wiki/Internal_combustion_engine "Internal combustion engine")
continued at a rapid pace, with [multi-valve](/wiki/Multi-valve "Multi-valve")
and [overhead camshaft](/wiki/Overhead_camshaft "Overhead camshaft") engines
produced at the high end, and [V8](/wiki/V8_engine "V8 engine"),
[V12](/wiki/V12_engine "V12 engine"), and even [V16 engines](/wiki/V16_engine
"V16 engine") conceived for the ultra-rich. Also in 1919, [hydraulic
brakes](/wiki/Hydraulic_brake "Hydraulic brake") were invented by [Malcolm
Loughead](/wiki/Malcolm_Loughead "Malcolm Loughead") (co-founder of
[Lockheed](/wiki/Lockheed_Corporation "Lockheed Corporation")); they were
adopted by [Duesenberg](/wiki/Duesenberg "Duesenberg") for their 1921 Model
A.[28] Three years later, [Hermann
Rieseler](/w/index.php?title=Hermann_Rieseler&action=edit&redlink=1 "Hermann
Rieseler \(page does not exist\)") of [Vulcan
Motor](/wiki/Vulcan_\(motor_vehicles\) "Vulcan \(motor vehicles\)") invented
the first [automatic transmission](/wiki/Automatic_transmission "Automatic
transmission"), which had two-speed [planetary](/wiki/Epicyclic_gearing
"Epicyclic gearing") gearbox, [torque converter](/wiki/Torque_converter
"Torque converter"), and lockup [clutch](/wiki/Clutch "Clutch"); it never
entered production.[28] (Its like would only become an available option in
1940.)[28] Just at the end of the vintage era, [tempered
glass](/wiki/Toughened_glass "Toughened glass") (now standard equipment in
side windows) was invented in France.[28] In this era the revolutionary
[ponton design](/wiki/Ponton_\(automobile\) "Ponton \(automobile\)") of cars
without fully articulated [fenders](/wiki/Fender_\(vehicle\) "Fender
\(vehicle\)"), [running boards](/wiki/Running_board "Running board") and other
non-compact ledge elements was introduced in small series but mass production
of such cars was started much later (after WWII).

American auto companies in the 1920s expected they would soon sell six million
cars a year, but did not do so until 1955. Numerous companies disappeared.[41]
Between 1922 and 1925, the number of U.S. passenger car builders decreased
from 175 to 70. H. A. Tarantous, managing editor of _MoToR Member Society of
Automotive Engineers_ , in a [New York Times](/wiki/New_York_Times "New York
Times") article from 1925, suggested many were unable to raise production and
cope with falling prices (due to assembly line production), especially for
low-priced cars. The new [pyroxylin](/wiki/Pyroxylin "Pyroxylin")-based
paints, eight cylinder engine, four wheel brakes, and balloon tires as the
biggest trends for 1925.[42]

Examples of period vehicles:[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

  * 1922–1939 [Austin 7](/wiki/Austin_7 "Austin 7") — one of the most widely copied vehicles ever, serving as a template for cars around the world, from [BMW](/wiki/BMW "BMW") to [Nissan](/wiki/Nissan "Nissan").
  * 1922–1931 [Lancia Lambda](/wiki/Lancia_Lambda "Lancia Lambda") — very advanced car for the time, first car to feature a load-bearing [monocoque](/wiki/Monocoque "Monocoque") and [independent front suspension](/wiki/Independent_suspension "Independent suspension").[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
  * 1924–1929 [Bugatti Type 35](/wiki/Bugatti_Type_35 "Bugatti Type 35") — one of the most successful racing cars of all time, with over 1,000 victories in five years.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
  * 1925–1928 [Hanomag 2 / 10 PS](/wiki/Hanomag_2_/_10_PS "Hanomag 2 / 10 PS") — early example of [ponton styling](/wiki/Ponton_\(automobile\) "Ponton \(automobile\)").
  * 1927–1931 [Ford Model A (1927-1931)](/wiki/Ford_Model_A_\(1927-1931\) "Ford Model A \(1927-1931\)") — after keeping the brass era [Model T](/wiki/Ford_Model_T "Ford Model T") in production for too long, Ford broke from the past by restarting its model series with the 1927 Model A. More than 4 million were produced, making it the best-selling model of the era. The Ford Model A was a prototype for the beginning of Soviet mass car production (GAZ A).
  * 1930 [Cadillac V-16](/wiki/Cadillac_V-16 "Cadillac V-16") — developed at the height of the vintage era, the [V16](/wiki/V16_engine "V16 engine")-powered [Cadillac](/wiki/Cadillac_\(automobile\) "Cadillac \(automobile\)") would join [Bugatti](/wiki/Bugatti "Bugatti")'s [Royale](/wiki/Bugatti_Royale "Bugatti Royale") as the most legendary ultra-luxury cars of the era.

Main article: [Classic car](/wiki/Classic_car "Classic car")

The pre-war part of the classic era began with the [Great
Depression](/wiki/Great_Depression "Great Depression") in 1930, and ended with
the recovery after World War II, commonly placed at 1946. It was in this
period that integrated [fenders](/wiki/Fender_\(vehicle\) "Fender
\(vehicle\)") and fully closed [bodies](/wiki/Car_body_style "Car body style")
began to dominate sales, with the new
[saloon/sedan](/wiki/Sedan_\(automobile\) "Sedan \(automobile\)") body style
even incorporating a [trunk or boot](/wiki/Trunk_\(automobile\) "Trunk
\(automobile\)") at the rear for storage. The old open-top
[runabouts](/wiki/Runabout_\(car\) "Runabout \(car\)"),
[phaetons](/wiki/Phaeton_body "Phaeton body"), and [touring
cars](/wiki/Touring_car "Touring car") were largely phased out by the end of
the classic era as wings, running boards, and [headlights](/wiki/Headlamp
"Headlamp") were gradually integrated with the body of the car.

By the 1930s, most of the mechanical technology used in today's automobiles
had been invented, although some things were later "re-invented", and credited
to someone else. For example, [front-wheel drive](/wiki/Front-wheel_drive
"Front-wheel drive") was re-introduced by André [Citroën](/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn
"Citroën") with the launch of the [_Traction
Avant_](/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_Traction_Avant "Citroën Traction Avant") in 1934,
though it had appeared several years earlier in road cars made by
[Alvis](/wiki/Alvis_Car_and_Engineering_Company_Ltd "Alvis Car and Engineering
Company Ltd") and [Cord](/wiki/Cord_Automobile "Cord Automobile"), and in
racing cars by Miller (and may have appeared as early as 1897). In the same
vein, independent suspension was originally conceived by [Amédée
Bollée](/wiki/Am%C3%A9d%C3%A9e_Boll%C3%A9e "Amédée Bollée") in 1873, but not
put in production until appearing on the low-volume [Mercedes-Benz
380](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_380_\(1933\) "Mercedes-Benz 380 \(1933\)") in 1933,
which prodded American makers to use it more widely.[38] In 1930, the number
of [auto manufacturers](/wiki/Automotive_industry "Automotive industry")
declined sharply as the industry consolidated and matured, thanks in part to
the effects of the [Great Depression](/wiki/Great_Depression "Great
Depression").

Exemplary pre-war automobiles:[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

  * 1932–1939 [Alvis Speed 20](/wiki/Alvis_Speed_20 "Alvis Speed 20") — the first with all-[synchromesh gearbox](/wiki/Synchromesh "Synchromesh")[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
  * 1932–1948 [Ford V-8 (Model B)](/wiki/Ford_Model_B_\(1932\) "Ford Model B \(1932\)") — introduction of the [flathead V8](/wiki/Ford_Flathead_engine "Ford Flathead engine") in mainstream vehicles
  * 1934–1938 [Tatra 77](/wiki/Tatra_77 "Tatra 77") — first serial-produced car with aerodynamical design
  * 1934–1940 [Bugatti Type 57](/wiki/Bugatti_Type_57 "Bugatti Type 57") — a singular refined automobile for the wealthy
  * 1934–1956 [Citroën Traction Avant](/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_Traction_Avant "Citroën Traction Avant") — the first mass-produced [front-wheel drive](/wiki/Front-wheel_drive "Front-wheel drive") car, built with [monocoque](/wiki/Monocoque "Monocoque") chassis
  * 1936–1955 [MG T series](/wiki/MG_T-type "MG T-type") — sports cars
  * 1938–2003 [Volkswagen Beetle](/wiki/Volkswagen_Beetle "Volkswagen Beetle") — a design that was produced for over 60 years with over 20 million units assembled in several counties
  * 1936–1939 [Rolls-Royce Phantom III](/wiki/Rolls-Royce_Phantom_III "Rolls-Royce Phantom III") — [V12 engine](/wiki/V12_engine "V12 engine")

Main article: [Classic car](/wiki/Classic_car "Classic car")

A major change in [automobile design](/wiki/Automotive_design "Automotive
design") since World War II was the popularity of
[ponton](/wiki/Ponton_\(automobile\) "Ponton \(automobile\)") style, in which
running boards were eliminated and fenders were incorporated into the body.
Among the first representatives of the style were the Soviet [GAZ-M20
Pobeda](/wiki/GAZ-M20_Pobeda "GAZ-M20 Pobeda") (1946), British [Standard
Vanguard](/wiki/Standard_Vanguard "Standard Vanguard") (1947), United States
[Studebaker Champion](/wiki/Studebaker_Champion "Studebaker Champion") and
[Kaiser](/wiki/Frazer_\(automobile\) "Frazer \(automobile\)") (1946), as well
as the low-production Czech luxury [Tatra T600 Tatraplan](/wiki/Tatra_600
"Tatra 600") (1946) and the Italian [Cisitalia 220](/wiki/Cisitalia
"Cisitalia") sports car (1947).

Automobile design and production finally emerged from the military orientation
and other shadow of war in 1949, the year that in the United States saw the
introduction of high-[compression](/wiki/Compression_ratio "Compression
ratio") [V8 engines](/wiki/V8_engine "V8 engine") and modern bodies from
[General Motors](/wiki/General_Motors "General Motors")'
[Oldsmobile](/wiki/Oldsmobile "Oldsmobile") and
[Cadillac](/wiki/Cadillac_\(automobile\) "Cadillac \(automobile\)") brands.
[Hudson](/wiki/Hudson_Motor_Car_Company "Hudson Motor Car Company") introduced
the "step-down" design with the 1948 [Commodore](/wiki/Hudson_Commodore
"Hudson Commodore"), which placed the passenger compartment down inside the
perimeter of the frame, that was one of the first new-design postwar cars made
and featured trend-setting slab-side styling.[43] The [unibody](/wiki/Unibody
"Unibody")/[strut-suspended](/wiki/MacPherson_strut "MacPherson strut") 1951
[Ford Consul](/wiki/Ford_Consul "Ford Consul") joined the 1948 [Morris
Minor](/wiki/Morris_Minor "Morris Minor") and 1949 [Rover P4](/wiki/Rover_P4
"Rover P4") in the automobile market in the United Kingdom. In Italy, [Enzo
Ferrari](/wiki/Enzo_Ferrari "Enzo Ferrari") was beginning his [250
series](/wiki/Ferrari_250 "Ferrari 250"), just as [Lancia](/wiki/Lancia
"Lancia") introduced the revolutionary [V6](/wiki/V6_engine "V6
engine")-powered [Aurelia](/wiki/Lancia_Aurelia "Lancia Aurelia").

Throughout the 1950s, [engine](/wiki/Motive_power "Motive power")
[power](/wiki/Power_\(physics\) "Power \(physics\)") and vehicle speeds rose,
designs became more integrated and artful, and automobiles were marketed
internationally. [Alec Issigonis](/wiki/Alec_Issigonis "Alec Issigonis")'
[Mini](/wiki/Mini "Mini") and [Fiat](/wiki/Fiat "Fiat")'s [500](/wiki/Fiat_500
"Fiat 500") diminutive cars were introduced in Europe, while the similar [kei
car](/wiki/Kei_car "Kei car") class became popular in Japan. The [Volkswagen
Beetle](/wiki/Volkswagen_Beetle "Volkswagen Beetle") continued production
after [Hitler](/wiki/Adolf_Hitler "Adolf Hitler") and began exports to other
nations, including the United States. At the same time, Nash introduced the
[Nash Rambler](/wiki/Nash_Rambler "Nash Rambler"), the first successful modern
compact car made in the United States,[44] while the standard models produced
by the "Big Three" domestic automakers grew ever larger in size, featuring
increasing amounts of chrome trim, and luxury was exemplified by the [Cadillac
Eldorado Brougham](/wiki/Cadillac_Eldorado "Cadillac Eldorado"). The markets
in Europe expanded with new small-sized automobiles, as well as expensive
[grand tourers](/wiki/Grand_tourer "Grand tourer") (GT), like the [Ferrari
America](/wiki/Ferrari_America "Ferrari America").

The market changed in the 1960s, as the United States "Big Three" automakers
began facing competition from imported cars, the European makers adopted
advanced technologies and Japan emerged as a car-producing nation. Japanese
companies began to export some of their more popular selling cars in Japan
internationally, such as the [Toyota Corolla](/wiki/Toyota_Corolla "Toyota
Corolla"), [Toyota Corona](/wiki/Toyota_Corona "Toyota Corona"), [Nissan
Sunny](/wiki/Nissan_Sunny "Nissan Sunny"), and [Nissan
Bluebird](/wiki/Nissan_Bluebird "Nissan Bluebird") in the mid-1960s. The
success of [American Motors](/wiki/American_Motors "American Motors")'
compact-sized [Rambler](/wiki/Rambler_\(automobile\) "Rambler \(automobile\)")
models spurred GM and Ford to introduce their own downsized cars in 1960.
Performance engines became a focus of marketing by United States automakers,
exemplified by the era's [muscle cars](/wiki/Muscle_car "Muscle car"). In
1964, the [Ford Mustang](/wiki/Ford_Mustang "Ford Mustang") developed a new
market segment, the [pony car](/wiki/Pony_car "Pony car"). New models to
compete with the Mustang included the [Chevrolet
Camaro](/wiki/Chevrolet_Camaro "Chevrolet Camaro"), [AMC
Javelin](/wiki/AMC_Javelin "AMC Javelin"), and [Plymouth
Barracuda](/wiki/Plymouth_Barracuda "Plymouth Barracuda"). [Captive
imports](/wiki/Captive_import "Captive import") and [badge
engineering](/wiki/Badge_engineering "Badge engineering") increased in the
United States and the UK as [amalgamated](/wiki/Consolidation_\(business\)
"Consolidation \(business\)") groups such as the [British Motor
Corporation](/wiki/British_Motor_Corporation "British Motor Corporation")
consolidated the market. BMC's space-saving Mini, which first appeared in
1959, was marketed under the [Austin](/wiki/Austin_Motor_Company "Austin Motor
Company") and [Morris](/wiki/Morris_Motors "Morris Motors") names, until Mini
became a [marque](/wiki/Marque "Marque") in its own right in 1969.[45]
Competition increased, with [Studebaker](/wiki/Studebaker "Studebaker"), a
pioneering automaker, shutting down, and the trend for consolidation reached
Italy where niche makers like [Maserati](/wiki/Maserati "Maserati"),
[Ferrari](/wiki/Ferrari "Ferrari"), and [Lancia](/wiki/Lancia "Lancia") were
acquired by larger companies. By the end of the decade, the number of
automobile marques had been greatly reduced.

Technology developments included the widespread use of [independent
suspensions](/wiki/Independent_suspension "Independent suspension"), wider
application of [fuel injection](/wiki/Fuel_injection "Fuel injection"), and an
increasing focus on [safety](/wiki/Automobile_safety "Automobile safety") in
[automotive design](/wiki/Automotive_design "Automotive design"). Innovations
during the 1960s included [NSU](/wiki/NSU_Motorenwerke_AG "NSU Motorenwerke
AG")'s [Wankel engine](/wiki/Wankel_engine "Wankel engine"), the [gas
turbine](/wiki/Gas_turbine "Gas turbine"), and the
[turbocharger](/wiki/Turbocharger "Turbocharger"). Of these, only the last
endured, pioneered by [General Motors](/wiki/General_Motors_Corporation
"General Motors Corporation"), and adopted by [BMW](/wiki/BMW "BMW") and
[Saab](/wiki/Saab_Automobile "Saab Automobile"), later seeing mass-market use
during the 1980s by [Chrysler](/wiki/Chrysler "Chrysler"). [Mazda](/wiki/Mazda
"Mazda") continued developing its [Wankel](/wiki/Mazda_Wankel_engine "Mazda
Wankel engine") engine, in spite of problems in longevity, emissions, and fuel
economy. Other Wankel licensees, including [Mercedes-Benz](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz
"Mercedes-Benz") and GM, never put their designs into production because of
engineering and manufacturing problems, as well as the lessons from the 1973
oil crisis.

The 1970s were turbulent years for automakers and buyers with major events
reshaping the industry such as the [1973 oil crisis](/wiki/1973_oil_crisis
"1973 oil crisis"), stricter [automobile emissions
control](/wiki/Automobile_emissions_control "Automobile emissions control")
and safety requirements, increasing exports by the Japanese and European
automakers, as well as growth in inflation and the stagnant economic
conditions in many nations. Smaller-sized grew in popularity. The United
States saw the establishment of the [subcompact](/wiki/Subcompact_car
"Subcompact car") segment with the introduction of the [AMC
Gremlin](/wiki/AMC_Gremlin "AMC Gremlin"), followed by the [Chevrolet
Vega](/wiki/Chevrolet_Vega "Chevrolet Vega") and [Ford Pinto](/wiki/Ford_Pinto
"Ford Pinto"). The [station wagons (estate, break, kombi,
universal)](/wiki/Station_wagon "Station wagon") body design was popular, as
well as increasing sales of non-commercial [all-wheel drive](/wiki/All-
wheel_drive "All-wheel drive") [off-road vehicles](/wiki/Off-road_vehicle
"Off-road vehicle").

To the end of the 20th century, the United States [Big
Three](/wiki/Big_Three_\(automobile_manufacturers\) "Big Three \(automobile
manufacturers\)") (GM, Ford, and Chrysler) partially lost their leading
position, Japan became for a while the world's leader of car production and
cars began to be mass manufactured in new Asian, East European, and other
countries.

Notable exemplary post-war cars:[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

  * 1946–1958 [GAZ-M20 Pobeda](/wiki/GAZ-M20_Pobeda "GAZ-M20 Pobeda") — Soviet car with full ponton design
  * 1947–1958 [Standard Vanguard](/wiki/Standard_Vanguard "Standard Vanguard") — British mass-market car with full ponton design
  * 1948–1971 [Morris Minor](/wiki/Morris_Minor "Morris Minor") – an early post-war car exported around the world
  * 1953–1971 [Chevrolet Bel Air](/wiki/Chevrolet_Bel_Air "Chevrolet Bel Air") and 1953–2002 [Cadillac Eldorado Brougham](/wiki/Cadillac_Eldorado_Brougham "Cadillac Eldorado Brougham") – first generations were representative of [tailfin](/wiki/Car_tailfin "Car tailfin") design
  * 1955–1976 [Citroën DS](/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_DS "Citroën DS") — aerodynamic design and innovative technology, awarded third place as [Car of the 20th Century](/wiki/Car_of_the_Century "Car of the Century")
  * 1959–2000 [Mini](/wiki/Mini "Mini") — a radical and innovative small car that was manufactured for four decades; awarded second place as [Car of the 20th Century](/wiki/Car_of_the_Century "Car of the Century")
  * 1960-1990 [Volkswagen Brasília](/wiki/Volkswagen_Bras%C3%ADlia "Volkswagen Brasília")
  * 1961–1975 [Jaguar E-type](/wiki/Jaguar_E-type "Jaguar E-type") — a classic sports car design
  * 1963–1989 [Porsche 911](/wiki/Porsche_911 "Porsche 911") – a sports car was awarded fifth place as [Car of the 20th Century](/wiki/Car_of_the_Century "Car of the Century")
  * 1964–present [Ford Mustang](/wiki/Ford_Mustang "Ford Mustang") — the [pony car](/wiki/Pony_car "Pony car") that became one of the best-selling cars of the era
  * 1966–end of the 20th century [Fiat 124](/wiki/Fiat_124 "Fiat 124") — an Italian car that was produced under license in many other counties including the [Soviet Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union")
  * 1966–1971 [Subaru 1000](/wiki/Subaru_1000 "Subaru 1000") – one of the first Japanese built sedans using a [boxer engine](/wiki/Boxer_engine "Boxer engine"), [front wheel drive](/wiki/Front_wheel_drive "Front wheel drive") and introducing the "[double offset joint](/wiki/Constant-velocity_joint "Constant-velocity joint")" drive shaft to the front wheels
  * 1967 [NSU Ro 80](/wiki/NSU_Ro_80 "NSU Ro 80") — the basic wedge profile of this design was emulated in subsequent decades,[46] unlike its Wankel engine
  * late 1960s-early 1980s [Gurgel BR-800](/wiki/Gurgel_BR-800 "Gurgel BR-800")
  * late 1960s-early 1980s [Gurgel Supermini](/wiki/Gurgel_Supermini "Gurgel Supermini")
  * 1969 [Datsun 240Z](/wiki/Datsun_240Z "Datsun 240Z") — Japanese sports car[47]
  * 1980–1988 [AMC Eagle](/wiki/AMC_Eagle "AMC Eagle") — the first mass-produced full-time all-wheel drive car[48]

Toyota_Corolla_Style_%282016_European_version%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Toyota_Corolla_Style_\(2016_European_version\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Toyota_Corolla_Style_\(2016_European_version\).jpg "Enlarge")

The [Toyota Corolla](/wiki/Toyota_Corolla "Toyota Corolla") is the world's
[best-selling](/wiki/List_of_best-selling_automobiles "List of best-selling
automobiles") nameplate.

The modern era is normally defined as the 25 years preceding the current
year.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_] The modern era has been one of increasing
[standardisation](/wiki/Standardization "Standardization"), [platform
sharing](/wiki/Automobile_platform "Automobile platform"), [computer-aided
design](/wiki/Computer-aided_design "Computer-aided design"), to reduce costs
and development time and increasing use of electronic for both engine
management and entertainment systems.

Some particular contemporary developments are the proliferation of
[front-](/wiki/Front-wheel_drive "Front-wheel drive") and [all-wheel
drive](/wiki/All-wheel_drive "All-wheel drive"), the adoption of the [diesel
engine](/wiki/Diesel_engine "Diesel engine"), and the ubiquity of [fuel
injection](/wiki/Fuel_injection "Fuel injection"). Most modern passenger cars
are front-wheel-drive [monocoque](/wiki/Monocoque
"Monocoque")/[unibody](/wiki/Unibody "Unibody") designs, with [transversely
mounted engines](/wiki/Transverse_engine "Transverse engine").

[Body styles](/wiki/Car_body_style "Car body style") have changed as well in
the modern era. Three types, the [hatchback](/wiki/Hatchback "Hatchback"),
[sedan](/wiki/Sedan_\(automobile\) "Sedan \(automobile\)"), and [sport utility
vehicle](/wiki/Sport_utility_vehicle "Sport utility vehicle"), dominate
today's market.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] All originally emphasised practicality, but
have mutated into today's high-powered luxury [crossover
SUV](/wiki/Crossover_SUV "Crossover SUV"), [sports wagon](/wiki/Station_wagon
"Station wagon") and two-volume [Large MPV](/wiki/Large_MPV "Large MPV"). The
rise of [pickup trucks](/wiki/Pickup_truck "Pickup truck") in the United
States and SUVs worldwide has changed the face of motoring with these "trucks"
coming to command more than half of the world automobile market.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] There
was also the introduction of the [MPV class](/wiki/Large_MPV "Large MPV")
(smaller non-commercial passenger [minivans](/wiki/Minivan "Minivan")), among
the first of which were the French [Renault Espace](/wiki/Renault_Espace
"Renault Espace") and the [Chrysler minivan](/wiki/Chrysler_S_platform
"Chrysler S platform") versions in the United States

The modern era has also seen rapidly improving [fuel
efficiency](/wiki/Fuel_economy_in_automobiles "Fuel economy in automobiles")
and engine output. The [automobile
emissions](/wiki/Automobile_emissions_control "Automobile emissions control")
concerns have been eased with computerised [engine management
systems](/wiki/Engine_control_unit "Engine control unit").

The [economic crisis of 2008](/wiki/Financial_crisis_of_2007-08 "Financial
crisis of 2007-08") cut almost a third of light vehicle sales from Chrysler,
Toyota, Ford, and Nissan. It also subtracted about a fourth of Honda's sales
and about a seventh of sales from General Motors.[49]

Since 2009, China has become the world's largest car manufacturer with
production greater than Japan, the United States, and all of Europe. Besides
large growth of car production in Asian and other countries, there has been
growth in transnational [corporate groups](/wiki/Corporate_group "Corporate
group"), with the production of transnational automobiles sharing the same
[platforms](/wiki/Automobile_platform "Automobile platform") as well as [badge
engineering](/wiki/Badge_engineering "Badge engineering") or re-badging to
suit different markets and consumer segments.

Since the end of the 20th century, several award competitions for cars and
trucks have become widely known, such as [European Car of the
Year](/wiki/European_Car_of_the_Year "European Car of the Year"), [Car of the
Year Japan](/wiki/Car_of_the_Year_Japan "Car of the Year Japan"), [North
American Car of the Year](/wiki/North_American_Car_of_the_Year "North American
Car of the Year"), [World Car of the Year](/wiki/World_Car_of_the_Year "World
Car of the Year"), [Truck of the Year](/wiki/Truck_of_the_Year "Truck of the
Year"), and [International Car of the
Year](/wiki/International_Car_of_the_Year "International Car of the Year").
Also, a [Car of the Century](/wiki/Car_of_the_Century "Car of the Century")
award was held in which in the US the [Ford Model T](/wiki/Ford_Model_T "Ford
Model T") was named as most influential car of the 20th century.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Exemplary modern cars:[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

  * 1966–present [Toyota Corolla](/wiki/Toyota_Corolla "Toyota Corolla") – a Japanese [saloon/sedan](/wiki/Sedan_\(automobile\) "Sedan \(automobile\)") that has become the best-selling nameplate of all time, with over 40 million sold across 11 generations through July 2013.[50]
  * 1966–1992 [Oldsmobile Toronado](/wiki/Oldsmobile_Toronado "Oldsmobile Toronado") – Introduced electronic [anti-lock braking system](/wiki/Anti-lock_braking_system "Anti-lock braking system"),[51] and [airbag](/wiki/Airbag "Airbag") [52] First modern-era American car with front wheel drive.
  * 1973–present [Mercedes-Benz S-Class](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_S-Class "Mercedes-Benz S-Class") – [Seat belt](/wiki/Seat_belt "Seat belt") pretensioner, and electronic [traction control system](/wiki/Traction_control_system "Traction control system")
  * 1975–present [BMW 3 Series](/wiki/BMW_3_Series "BMW 3 Series") – the 3 Series has been on _Car and Driver_ magazine's annual Ten Best list 17 times
  * 1977–present [Honda Accord](/wiki/Honda_Accord "Honda Accord") saloon/sedan — a Japanese sedan that became popular in the United States
  * 1983–present [Chrysler minivans](/wiki/Dodge_Caravan "Dodge Caravan") – the two-box [minivan](/wiki/Minivan "Minivan") design nearly pushed the [station wagon](/wiki/Station_wagon "Station wagon") out of the market
  * 1984–present [Renault Espace](/wiki/Renault_Espace "Renault Espace") — first mass one-volume car of non-commercial MPV class
  * 1986–present [Ford Taurus](/wiki/Ford_Taurus "Ford Taurus") — this [mid-sized](/wiki/Mid-size_car "Mid-size car") front-wheel drive sedan dominated the United States market in the late-1980s
  * 1997–present [Toyota Prius](/wiki/Toyota_Prius "Toyota Prius"), launched in the Japanese market and became the best known [hybrid electric vehicle](/wiki/Hybrid_electric_vehicle "Hybrid electric vehicle") and also the world's top selling hybrid.[53]
  * 1998–present [Ford Focus](/wiki/Ford_Focus_\(international\) "Ford Focus \(international\)") — one of the most popular [hatchbacks](/wiki/Hatchback "Hatchback") and [Ford](/wiki/Ford_Motor_Company "Ford Motor Company")'s best selling [world car](/wiki/World_car "World car")
  * 2008–present [Tata Nano](/wiki/Tata_Nano "Tata Nano") — an inexpensive (₹100,000, ≈ $2200), rear-engined, four-passenger city car aimed primarily at the Indian domestic market
  * 2008–2012 [Tesla Roadster](/wiki/Tesla_Roadster "Tesla Roadster") — first highway-capable all-electric vehicle in [serial production](/wiki/Serial_production "Serial production") for sale in the United States in the modern era. Sold about 2,500 units worldwide.
  * 2008–2013 [BYD F3DM](/wiki/BYD_F3DM "BYD F3DM") – first highway-capable [series production](/wiki/Series_production "Series production") [plug-in hybrid](/wiki/Plug-in_hybrid "Plug-in hybrid"), launched in China in December 2008, sold over 2,300 units.[54][55]
  * 2009–present, [Mitsubishi i-MiEV](/wiki/Mitsubishi_i-MiEV "Mitsubishi i-MiEV") – first highway-capable series production [all-electric car](/wiki/All-electric_car "All-electric car"), launched in Japan in July 2009 for fleet customers, and in April 2010 for retail customers. [Rebadged](/wiki/Badge_engineering "Badge engineering") versions of the i MiEV are sold in Europe by [PSA Peugeot Citroën](/wiki/PSA_Peugeot_Citro%C3%ABn "PSA Peugeot Citroën") (PSA) as the Peugeot iOn and Citroën C-Zero.[56][57]
  * 2010–present, [Nissan Leaf](/wiki/Nissan_Leaf "Nissan Leaf") and [Chevrolet Volt](/wiki/Chevrolet_Volt "Chevrolet Volt") — all-electric car and plug-in hybrid correspondingly, launched in December 2010, are the world's top selling [mass production](/wiki/Mass_production "Mass production") vehicles of their kind.[58] As of early December 2015, global Leaf sales totaled 200,000 units and Volt sales over 100,000.[59]
  * 2012–present, [Tesla Model S](/wiki/Tesla_Model_S "Tesla Model S") – Introduced in 2012, the Model S quickly climbed up sales. It was ranked as the world's best selling plug-in electric vehicle in 2015.[60] It was also named car of the century by [Car and Driver](/wiki/Car_and_Driver "Car and Driver").[61]
